Dear Sir,

I beg to report that at my recent inspection of the Six Nations Schools and Class rooms I found the following matters requiring immediate attention:

School No. 1 - Teacher Miss Julia Jamieson.
This school is much overcrowded the attendance being 51. The outhouses are in a bad state requiring repair and a general overhaul at a cost of about $25.00.

School No. 2 - Teacher Senior Room, Miss Vera Davis.
Teacher Junior Room, Miss Nora Jamieson.
Miss Davis requires a new chair, the one she uses being broken beyond repair, and a new bell rope.
The board walk approach to the school is broken, full of holes and dangerous. I recommend that either a crushed stone walk with concrete curbs, or a concrete walk be installed.
The fence is in a bad state needing a number of new pickets.
The down pipes from the eave troughs have blown off and become lost in two places, and the eave trough flow is undermining the foundation.
There is one window broken.
The Class rooms are in good condition, and all else in this school is entirely satisfactory.

School No. 3 - Teacher Miss Sylvia Jamieson.
This school is greatly overcrowded, the attendance being 62.
The pump is broken and useless and should be replaced.
The outhouses need repair.
School No. 4 - Teacher Miss Elva Miller.
This school is satisfactory, the attendance being 27.
The pump is broken and practically useless.

School No. 5 - Teacher Miss Mildred Frohman.
The outhouses are in a very bad state. They are hardly usable. The pits are full, and the majority of the boards require to be replaced. I estimate $50.00.
There is no pump, the old one having been broken for some time.
The hinges on the front door need repair.
The teacher complains that she has not seen her Trustee, Mr. Ed. P. Garlow since June. This Trustee does not attend to his duties satisfactorily, although he is a Councillor.

School No. 6 - Teacher Mr. Winton Loft.
The outhouses are in need of repair.
The school is overcrowded, the attendance being 51.
I think room could be made for from six to eight desks by moving the stove.
Three window panes are broken.

School No. 7 - Teacher Mr. Melvin Johnson
Rather crowded, attendance being 47.
The outhouses need repair.
Otherwise satisfactory.

School No. 8 - Teacher Mr. Oliver Smith
Small attendance 30. Good School.
Slight repairs to outhouses.
Rooms rather dark.
Teacher asks for another Black Board, 9 ft. x 3 ft.

School No. 9 - Teacher Miss Helen Miller.
This school is in a dangerous condition, the wall bulging at the north-west corner. I have reported upon this under separate cover.
This is one of the schools which I recommended last year for re-construction.
It is small and very much overcrowded there being but 36 desks and 39 pupils, exclusive of the 8 Mississauga children for which there is no room.
If possible, instead of merely shoring up the back wall the room should be enlarged.
For present emergencies a further six or eight seats might be squeezed in by moving back the stove nearer to the back wall.
School No. 10 - Teacher Miss Mary Hill
Average attendance 27 - 42 on list.
The outhouses good.
Everything satisfactory.

School No. 11 - Senior Teacher, Miss Violet Hall
Junior Teacher, Miss Mina Hill
Satisfactory except that the outhouses are much too close to the school and to the Teachers residence.
The Teachers complain both of the odour and the multitude of flies.
These outhouses should be moved away altogether.

Resume of report
Pumps - The system of pump and water supply in all Schools needs revision.
The pumps are open to the weather, to violent use by children and outsiders, and pump and well repairs form a considerable item in consequence.
I think that a definite universal pattern of pump should be adopted as the old pumps wear out.
Old pumps should be turned in and stored in the Roads Storage Yard where their unbroken parts would be available for repairs to others.
A small lock up well house should be erected over each pump and pitchers or filters supplied to be kept full by the Janitors. The children who swing on the pumps and otherwise break them should not be allowed near them, and their use for watering cattle or other purposes by others should not be permitted.

Relief of congestion.
Owing to the depression, and the return to the Reserve of Indian families which work elsewhere in more prosperous times, some of our Schools show an increase which overcrowds them beyond their capacity and that of the Teacher to instruct them properly. This congestion is worse in No. 1, No. 3, No. 6 and No. 7. Number 9 being the worst I have dealt with under separate cover.
The congestion in Nos. 1, 3, 6 and 7 might be temporarily met by moving two walls at convenient locations, employing teachers who occasionally do supply duty temporarily.

Your obedient servant,

Lt.Col. C.E.Morgan

Supt. Six Nations.
Ottawa, November 24, 1931.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 14th instant, reporting the various repairs, etc., required at each of the Indian Day Schools on the Six Nations Reserve. In this connection I would request that, in future, any matters affecting each of the schools form the subject of separate communications. This is necessary in order to meet the requirements of our filing system. We have separate files for each school and it was necessary, upon receipt of your letter, to have an extract made of your report regarding the needs at each school. You are being written separate letters regarding the repairs, etc., mentioned by you as being required at each of the schools.

Regarding the No. 1 School, it is noted that the outhouses are in bad condition requiring repairs and a general overhaul, at a cost of approximately $25. Our funds this year are extremely limited and it will only be possible to authorize the work absolutely required. You may arrange to have the outhouses thoroughly cleaned and any minor repairs required to place them in a serviceable condition until next summer carried out. Please see that no unnecessary expenditure is incurred. After this work has been completed, please forward an account, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the cost. You should keep the accounts for the expenditure incurred at each school separate, and, in forwarding the vouchers, state definitely thereon the school for which the work was carried out.

With reference to the resume of your report on the schools, regarding the system of pump and water supply, I have to request that you will inform the Department as to the type and cost of any new pumps that should be installed and the number required. Only the pumps absolutely necessary at the present time should be reported. The Department has no funds to provide a well house to be erected over each pump. When we have information as to the cost, etc., of the pumps, consideration will be given as to the new pumps that can be authorized.

As stated above, you will be informed in separate communications regarding the various repairs, etc., mentioned by you as being required at each of the other day schools.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Lt. Col. C. E. Morgan,
Indian Superintendent,

Sir:

"Repairs to Six Nations Schools"

In accordance with instructions received in Departmental letter 32-1-5 of April 1st, I have gone further into the estimates for repairs to Six Nations schools with a view to reducing them to the minimum of cost. The following repairs are absolutely necessary and estimates as furnished by the Road Superintendent, Mr. Cleveland Anderson, are as low as they can possibly be kept. These are merely estimates by the Road Superintendent. I will call for local tenders on the reserve from men who do this kind of work and I cannot guarantee that the tenders received will synchronize absolutely with the prices I have given you, but I will do my best to have the work done as cheaply as possible.

School No. 1. - Repair Outbuildings and fences; Material and Labour -- 15.55

School No. 2. - Repair Fences, Eave Pipe and Windows, new gutter pipe -- 21.25

It is reported that the doors are not safe in this school as they open outward instead of opening inward and on windy days are liable to sweep the children off the raised steps. These are cheap pine doors and should be replaced, but I have not been able to obtain an estimate for replacing these doors with better doors and altering the method of opening at the time of writing, and I wish to show them to Mr. Orr. It has been suggested that porches should be erected outside these doors, and I feel that the Department would possible consider the expense unwarranted at the present time.
School No. 3. -- Repair toilet and fences and Porch Floor; Porch supports are dangerous and must be replaced; concrete base of pump needs repair -- $50.00

School No. 4. -- Repair fences and pump. -- $15.00

School No. 5. -- Move Toilet and reshingel, Repair windows to school and doors. -- $50.00
Moving of the toilet can be left till another year.

School No. 6. -- Repair Toilet and Wood Shed; Smoke stack needs raising as the smoke blows down into the school room. I have, in consequence, raised this from $19 to -- $25.00

School No. 7. -- Repair Toilet and fence; -- $20.00

School No. 8. -- Repair Toilet and fence; -- $22.00

School No. 9. -- Being inspected by builders in accordance with Departmental instructions next Thursday, and I will report under separate cover.

School No. 10. -- Repair toilet and fence; -- $23.75

School No. 11. -- Repair fence and pump. Move Toilet. Repair Junior Room Floor. Roof over porch leaks and new locks required on side doors. I will, therefore, increase this to -- $100.00

The item for cement walk for No. 2 School I have entirely omitted this year. I am asking the Roads Committee to give enough gravel to fill in between two curbs which will be temporarily made from the old wooden side walk. Labour and time for this will, of course, have to be paid, for which I have not as yet obtained an estimate.

This totals $342.55 and I would ask for authority to expend $400, which leaves a margin and the Department may rely upon the price being cut down as low as possible.
Your obedient servant,

Lt. Col. C. E. Morgan.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 26th ultimo, stating, in detail, the repairs considered absolutely necessary at each of the Indian day schools on the Six Nations Reserve, together with an estimate of the cost.

In reply I have to say that the Department will approve of you arranging to have the various repairs as mentioned by you carried out at each of the schools. The total amount that may be expended for material and labour must not exceed the sum of $400, as this is the full amount available. This amount is to cover the cost of repairs at all the schools, with the exception of the No. 9 school. It is noted that you will forward a report as to what you would recommend be done at this school.

It is also noted you consider that the moving of the toilet at the No. 5 school could stand over for another year. However, if there are sufficient funds available from the above authorized amount, this work should be carried out when the other repairs are being made. If not, the moving of the toilet may stand over.

If there are sufficient funds, you may have the present pine doors at the No. 2 school replaced. We will have no funds this year to erect outside porches.

After the repairs have been carried out, please forward itemized accounts, in triplicate, showing, in detail, the expenditure incurred for each of the schools separately.

I am not enumerating the repairs, etc., to be carried out at each school, but only the work as mentioned in your letter above referred to is to be performed. The work should be completed before the schools reopen after the present summer holidays.

Your obedient servant,

Secretary.

Dear Sir:

"Cheque No. 10093 - $200."
Repairs to Six Nations School.

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter No. 32-1-5 of the 10th inst., reply to which has been delayed for information from the Roads Superintendent, Mr. Cleveland Anderson.

I will reply to your queries in the paragraphic order in which they appear in your letter:

(1) Mr. Anderson is employed as Roads Superintendent and is paid from Band funds and by the Province of Ontario. There is nothing in his appointment to debar him from undertaking work for the Department in other connections but as School Repairs are paid from appropriation neither the Indians nor the Province can be reasonably expected to bear the cost as would be the case if Mr. Anderson carried out this work in his capacity of Roads Superintendent. Mr. Anderson is the best man on the Reserve to carry out this supervision which he undertook cheerfully without interfering with his Road Superintendency work at my request, but if payment is refused on the grounds that he is a Departmental employee then a demand for a refund of the amount chargeable against the school grant on this work may be expected from the Roads Committee and the Provincial highways. This will complicate matters and create ill feeling all round. It will deprive me of Anderson's services for many such small jobs as he is most capable to undertake and add substance to the Indian contention, which I am anxious to avoid, that Band funds are used towards defraying school expenses.

It consequently seems that there are no grounds
whatever upon which we can ask Mr. Anderson for a refund. His efficiency leads to a considerable saving and higher standard in the work and I shall regard with regret any action by the Department that may bar me from engaging his services in future work of a similar description.

The pay lists of A. E. Hill and Oliver Curley were erroneously dated, separate services on different days being duplicated as having been performed on the same day. The pay sheets have been corrected and are returned herewith.

Yours faithfully,

Lt. Col. C. E. Morgan.
Supt. Six Nations.

MEMORANDUM

Dr. McGill:

On the 5th April the Auditor General called attention to a payment of $28.50, which was made by Col. Morgan, Six Nations Reserve, to Cleveland Anderson, the Roads Superintendent, for supervising some carpenter work done at No. 11 School. The Auditor General questions the propriety of this payment to Anderson in view of the fact that he is regularly employed as Roads Superintendent at a salary of $83.33 per month. (Until recently the rate was $75.00 a month), 50% of which salary is recoverable from the Ontario Government.

The matter was referred to Col. Morgan who has replied under date of April 21st, first letter down.

The point for decision is whether the Department wishes to authorize Col. Morgan to employ Anderson from time to time as foreman of small repair jobs so long as his road work is not interfered with and pay him from General Vote such wages as he may earn as foreman, in addition to his salary as Roads Superintendent.

I understand that in view of half of Anderson's salary being paid by the Ontario Government and half from Trust Funds that he is not regarded as a Civil Servant; his position is, therefore, not covered by a certificate from the Civil Service Commission. For this reason I do not think Sec. 17 of the Civil Service Act applies, which prohibits any Civil Servant from receiving compensation for more than one position.

Representative of the Treasury.

Sir:

Mr. Conley, of this Department, who recently visited your office, has drawn attention to the authority you should exercise in incurring expenditure for minor repairs at the Six Nations' Indian day schools.

In this connection I have to say that, in the case of any school requiring repairs to windows, through broken glass, or repairs to or renewing of stove pipes, where the cost does not exceed $10, you may, if the matter is more or less urgent, authorize the expenditure, forwarding accounts, in triplicate, properly certified, covering the cost. However, before any repairs are undertaken, the cost of which exceeds the above amount, you should report the matter to the Department, giving, in detail, full particulars as to the cost of materials and labour, as it is necessary that an encumbrance be raised to cover the funds required for the purpose. The cost of minor repairs which you are authorized to have undertaken, as stated above, is covered by a blanket encumbrance obtained from the Representative of the Treasury here. I may add that our funds this year for repairs are extremely limited, and no request should be made unless the work is absolutely urgent.

Repairs to Schools.

I asked W. H. Turnbull and Son of Brantford from whom the school furnaces were originally purchased to inspect them and report to me.

They say: "The two furnaces will require new steel jackets, new back pipes, some grate bars and possibly two lower decks. Doors and other castings may require to be renewed but the furnaces will have to be dismantled before an exact estimate can be furnished.

At present all we can say is that the entire cost will not exceed $250.00 and will likely be less when the furnaces are dismantled and their exact condition is ascertained."

One of these furnaces has been in use for great number of years and the other for 7 or 8 years and as it is impossible to continue to use them in their present condition owing to the danger by both a fire and escaping gas to the health of children I would ask the Department to be good enough to sanction this expenditure which will be kept down as far as possible.

No. 5 School.

The repairs to the boys outhouse are considerably heavier than I anticipated and will cost $10.00 instead of $2.50 in my estimate.

No. 6 School.

I made no allowance for gravel walks on school road which Mr. Hill estimates will cost $10.00.

No. 10 School.

Sir,

Repairs to Six Nations Schools.

I beg to inform you that I have inspected the repairs to the various schools, as enumerated in my previous correspondence, and approved by the Department, and found the work has been well carried out by Mr Albert Hill to whom I entrusted the work.

There remains a repair to the roof of No.2 School which was not known to be required when I originally outlined the necessary repairs and I have asked Mr Hill to put wooden covers on the small well houses that have been erected over the wells at No.6 and No.11 schools as, although the sides are three feet high, children may try to climb up them and fall into the wells, but the cost will be small.

Miss Monture, teacher at No.6, was there when I inspected, and asks for five additional standard pattern desks and seats, Nos;-

1 - No.2. 2. No.3. and 2.No.5., which please supply with as little delay as possible.

Your obedient servant,

Lt Col C.E.Morgan.

Superintendent Six Nations.

GEM/GEM.
Ottawa, September 4, 1934.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 28th ultimo, regarding the repairs which have been carried out to the various schools on the Six Nations reserve. The Department notes that you have inspected the work and found it has been satisfactorily completed. It is noted, also, that you have arranged to have wooden covers placed on the small well houses erected over the wells at the No. 6 and No. 11 Schools and that the cost will be small. Certified accounts, in triplicate, covering the expenditure incurred, should be forwarded in the usual manner.

Regarding the five additional desks required at the No. 6 School, I would request that you state the name of the manufacturer of the desks at present in use and also whether single or double desks are required. As it is necessary to have uniformity in seating equipment, if new desks are supplied, they should be of the same type as those at present in the school. The name of the manufacturer will, no doubt, be found stamped in the metal casing. When this information is received, consideration will be given as to whether the extra desks can be supplied.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

August 11th, 1936.

Sir:

I beg to submit for your consideration list of some of the most necessary repairs which should be carried out at the Six Nations day schools before the commencement of the school year.

It would be appreciated if the Dept. would forward me early instructions with regard to these in order the work can be completed before school begins.

School No.1:
The floor at the entrance to the school is sinking requiring new sill, but no exact estimate of the cost can be given without taking up the floor.

The Dept. will recollect that a similar job at No.11 school last year cost approximately $25.00.

One half of main front door is beyond repair, cost of new one approximately $6.50.

Around well has mud hole, requires a yard or two of gravel.

School No.2:
New grate in furnace is required and bell rope replaced.

School No.3:
New fence around school yard, Guard rail around porch.

School No.4:
New fence around school yard, verandah floor sinking requiring new sills, cost of repairs about $10.00.

School No.5:
Minor repairs to porch and doors required, also to roof owing to slight leak.

School No.6:
Fence on west side of school completely broken down.

School No.7:
Well needs cleaning, cost $5.00.
School No. 8
Porch floor sinking, new sills and planking required, cost about $10.00.

School No. 9
This school as previously reported needs completely rebuilding as ventilation, light and accommodation are insufficient, and any major repairs would be a waste of money. The walls are likely to crumble in sooner or later.

School No. 10
Stake fence all round school is broken down here and there, requiring some scantlings, stakes and post. $10.00 would cover cost of repairs.

School No. 11
Only repairs required is horse side walk, but this was authorized by the Dept. last winter, but weather would not permit, so it will be carried out now.

It will take 113 rods of nine wire woven fence to repair fences at schools 3-4 and 6. This will cost with discount $57.00.
In addition about 75 cedar and anchor posts will be required at the various schools for replacements, amounting to about $35.00 and whatever the labour costs of erecting these.

Each fence fence is in a really bad condition, permitting stock to roam in the school yards at will.

The windows inmost of the boys and girls toilets are broken and I am informed they are frequently damaged after school hours. As they must be replaced to prevent snow drifting in during the winter and to save constant replacement I would request to be permitted to place over each window the heavy wire screening farmers use over box stall windows. The cost will not be great as they are not large windows, and I am sure it will be an improvement and economy.

There are a few other minor repairs at all the schools not detailed such as locks and hinges on doors, but I trust my discretion in the matter is sufficient.

Your Obedient Servant

E. P. Randle

Major E. P. Randle
Supt. Six Nations

September 4th, 1936.

OTTAWA, Ontario.

Sir:

The returns of labour enclosed are for repairs to school floors, porches, sidewalks, etc., as authorized by your letter 32-1-5 of August 15th and letters 32-11-5, and 32-6-5 of December last.

I regret to say the repairs on No. 1 School floor were much more extensive than expected. On taking up the floor where it was sinking it was found that dry rot had set in on all the sills except two along the entire north half of the School floor. A slight knock or kick with one's feet and the sill end resting in the concrete slot crumbled away.

As a result the whole half of the floor had to be taken up and re-silled adding considerably to labour and material cost.

I am informed that this dry rot is caused by insufficient ventilation as the dampness that collects under the floor lies there instead of dispersing as it would if there were larger and more frequent ventilators.

I would request that cheques be issued with regard to this labour as follows:

D. Porter Jr. $8.80; D. Burning $22.05; O. Curley $22.05;
D. Porter Sr. $2.00; and C. Capten $3.85.

Your obedient servant,

E. P. Randle

I beg to submit for the consideration of the Department some work, repairs, etc., which I feel is necessary for certain of the Six Nation Day Schools.

It would be appreciated if your approval could be forwarded immediately if possible, in order the work may be carried out before the commencement of the school term.

No. 1. This school badly requires exterior painting, and would cost, using Indian labour and one coat of paint, approximately $50.00.

No. 2. This school is brick, but the window frames and doors outside require painting which I would recommend, as being in the Village its condition is most noticeable. It would cost approximately $20.00 to do the painting, and there are some repairs necessary to the eavestrough, costing about $15.00 including labour.

No. 4. This school must be eavestroughed complete at a cost, with labour of about $40.00.

No. 6. This school is in the worst condition of all and urgently requires painting inside and out at a cost of approximately $75.00 for one coat.

There are also some eavestroughing repairs necessary, costing about $15.00 including labour.

The stove is also warped and broken open on both sides and it is doubtful if it can be repaired. I would request the Department to give me authority to purchase a new one in the event of it being beyond repair. A new one is quoted locally at about $50.00 though hardware prices are constantly changing.
No. 7. This school should have one coat of paint on exterior at a cost with labour of approximately $50.00.

No. 8. This is the smallest school on the Reserve and badly requires painting inside and out at a cost of $60.00 with labour.

No. 9. This school as previously reported, urgently requires re-building and it is useless spending money on building repairs.

It however urgently requires a new woven wire fence. It will require 11 rods at 50¢ per rod or a cost of $5.50. In addition there will be labour costs and some posts, which can be bought off the Reserve at about .20¢ per post; Labour costs would be at .25¢ per hour.

A cupboard is also urgently required for books, etc.

No. 11. This is a two roomed school and should be painted inside and would cost approximately $60.00 with labour.

It is also urgently requires a new wire fence, taking 16 rods at .50¢ per rod or a cost of $8.00 plus a certain number of posts and labour costs, the same as at No. 9.

There are of course, in addition, some minor repairs to all schools, such as window panes, door knobs, latches, etc.

Also each school needs one or two new blinds, and a certain number of new stakes for the front fences which in each case are stake fences.

Most caretakers request extension ladders which they do not have, and it is really impossible for them to do much of the cleaning and repair work without them. A 33' extension ladder can be bought for $12.00 each.

All work and labour can be carried out by Indians.

Your obedient servant,

E. P. Randle

Major E. P. Randle.

Ottawa, August 13, 1937.

Dear Sir:

I desire to acknowledge receipt of your letter of August 10th, in which you submit, for the consideration of the Department, a list of repairs which you feel are necessary at a number of day schools on the Six Nations reserve. It is noted that you estimate the approximate cost of the repairs in each case.

You are authorized to proceed with these repairs, on the understanding that the work can be undertaken and accomplished by Indians and that the cost of the work will not exceed the amount stated by you in your communication. Dear Sir,

We have a crew putting on lightning protection in the Hagenville and Terralfoord districts at the present time and anyone through the Indian Reserve at Beaufort. I notice none of the schools are protected from lightning. This is a very rare occurrence in not having lightning protection on public schools. In fact, I don't think any more than five per cent are so protected.

As we will be here for a short time doing this work, I would like to know if you have any intentions of placing any protection on any of those schools in the Beaufort reserve. Please write to me at Hagenville if you want any work done on those buildings within a week.

Yours sincerely,

Sir:

Six Nations Indian Day Schools.

I beg to recommend after a recent inspection of the above schools, that the following improvements and repairs be carried out immediately while the summer holidays are on and the schools vacant.

No. 1 School. This school requires painting inside one coat will be sufficient, and using an Indian painter at .38¢ per hour would cost with material approximately $60.00.

Some eavestroughing repairs are also necessary, which will cost with labour approximately $20.00.

No. 3 School. This school requires painting inside and out at an approximate cost with labour of $120.00.

Three large blinds 40" x 8' at approximately $2.65 each, and two small 40" x 4' at approximately $1.55 each.

No. 4 School. Three large blinds 40" x 8' at approx. $2.65 and two small blinds at approx. $1.55.

No. 5 School. This school requires painting on the outside at a total cost with labour, of approximately $60.00.

A new stove is required, local quotations being around $55.00

Two new blinds costing approximately $3.23, 48" x 8'.

The fence surrounding the school is in good condition but requires taking down and restretching. This would require two men's time at .25¢ per hr. in addition to a few new fence posts.
No. 6 School. A new stove is required at this school costing approximately $55.00, and five blinds 40" x 6' at approximately $1.95 ea. Also a new fence, requiring about 40 rods at .50¢ per rod, with labour at .25¢ per hour and a certain number of posts at approximately .20¢ each.

A cement cover should replace an old wooden top over the well at a total cost of $20.00.

No. 7 School. One large blind at approximately $2.65 40" x 8' and two small blinds 40" x 4' at approximately $1.55 ea.

No. 9 School. Two large window blinds 36" x 8' at approximately $2.30 ea. and all the walls should be washed, which would cost just the labour at .25¢ per hour.

No. 10 School. This school require a new front door costing approximately $12.00 and a new desk for the teacher. Also four blinds 36" x 8' at approximately $2.30 each, and eavestroughing completely at a cost with labour of approximately $50.00.

No. 11 School. Five large window blinds 42" x 8' at approximately $2.65 ea. are required at this school.

Most of the schools have some minor repairs necessary, such as a leaky roof, broken sidewalks, pump troubles, or outhouse repairs, mostly requiring the services of a carpenter and a little material, which with the Department's approval will be carried out, using Indians at .38¢ per hour.

As none of the schools have flag poles, I would appreciate being given authority to place them at least six of the schools this summer. The original wooden poles rotted away and it is proposed to build the new ones from used piping, as the one recently built at the Council House, with a concrete base and would cost approximately $25.00 each.

Your obedient servant,

E. P. Randle

Indian Superintendent.

Major E. P. Randle.

Dear Sir:

The Department finds it necessary to return the account which you have submitted in favor of Scarfe & Company.

You quote official letter of July 26th as authority for the purchase of the paint and oil mentioned in the account. The quantities of these articles authorized in official letter of the 26th ultimo were much less than the quantity shown on the account and consequently it is presumed that this account covers the cost of paint and oil supplied to more than one school on the Six Nations Reserve.

In the circumstances, you should obtain new accounts from Scarfe & Company and each account should not exceed $50.00.

Yours truly,

Dear Sirs:

I must apologize in this matter. We have many hundreds of accounts to deal with in a month and though we try to take all reasonable care it occasionally happens that one is overlooked.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 12th instant our records show that cheque 28710 was issued on September 10, 1937, for an amount of $6.17 and forwarded to Wedlake's Hardware, 216 Colborne Street, Brantford, Ont. The cancelled cheque shows that the cheque was deposited on September 14, 1937.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,

Sir:

With reference to your 32-1-5 of the 17th June in connection with repairs to schools, the following major improvements are recommended.

No. 2 School. Painting throughout the interior of the building.

No. 10 School. Painting throughout exterior of building.

No. 3 School. Entire roof requires reshingling.

No. 11 School. East side of roof requires reshingling.

Approximately 22 gallons of paint will be required which can be obtained from local Manufacturers at $2.90 per gallon. Indian labour to carry out this work will cost approximately $100.00.

About 24 square of shingles will be required for the two schools referred to above and can be obtained locally for No. 13X quality at $4.75 per sq. In addition about 500 ft. of facia boards at $0.36 per foot, will be required. Indian labour for this work will cost approximately $70.00.

As the material required for both painting and shingling is not a large sum, it would expedite matters if this office could purchase same from firms on the approved list locally.

In addition there are minor repairs to most schools in the way of repairs to doors, floors, cupboards, savestroughs, etc. mostly a matter of labour and small quantities of material.
Your early approval would be appreciated as with the new school and the work at the Mohawk Institute considerable effort will be required to get all done by the time the school year commences.

Yours obedient servant,

E. P. Randle

Major E. P. Randle.
Indian Superintendent.

EPR/CB.
Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 2nd instant the following improvements to the day schools on the Six Nations Reserve are approved:

1. Painting the interior of the No. 2 school
2. Painting the exterior of the No. 10 school
3. Reshingling entire roof of No. 3 school
4. Reshingling east side of roof of No. 11 school
5. Making minor repairs to all schools

The paint required for the painting and the shingles and other material required for the re-roofing of the building may be purchased from firms on the approved list in order that the work may be completed before the schools re-open after the summer holidays.

An accountable cheque for $170.00 for labour will go forward under separate cover.

Please keep in mind that the total amount provided for repairs and improvements at the schools in the Six Nations Agency for the current fiscal year is $700.00, which amount should not be exceeded.

Yours truly,

Major H. P. Randle,
Supt. Six Nations,
Brantford, Ont.

Chief Training Division,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,

Sir:

The undermentioned major improvements are recommended to the various day schools to be carried out during the holiday season.

No. 5 School

Entire roof requires re-shingling.

No. 10 School

Painting throughout interior of building.

No. 3 School

Painting throughout interior and exterior of building.

Approximately 20 square of shingles would be required and can be obtained locally at $4.80 per square for No. 13X. Indian labour for this work will cost approximately $60.00.

About 37 gals. paint etc. will be required for the schools and can be purchased in 5 gallon lots at $3.05 per gallon. Labour for the work will cost approximately $100.00.
Most of the schools require minor repairs to either doors, windows, fences, porches and desks, etc., which may run into $100.00 for material and $50.00 for labour.

All work of course in every case would be done by Indians.

Kindly advise if these improvements and repairs may be carried out, and if so may an accountable cheque for payment of wages be forwarded please.

Yours truly,

E. P. Randle

Indian Superintendent.
Ottawa, July 16th, 1940.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 12th instant with reference to improvements required to the day schools on the Six Nations Reserve.

In preparing our Estimates for the current fiscal year it was only possible to include an amount of $500 for repairs and improvements to the Six Nations day schools. We have already expended an amount of $18.73 and there is therefore only $481.27 still available.

The total amount mentioned in your letter of the 12th instant is slightly over $500. Consequently it will be necessary to reduce the amount of work that you first contemplated doing.

A requisition should be forwarded for the materials required in order that these may be secured by our Purchasing Branch. It is understood, of course, that the cost of material and labour will not exceed the amount available, viz., $481.27.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Major E. P. Randle,
Indian Superintendent,
Brantford, Ont.

Ottawa, July 11, 1941.

Dear Sir:

In the current year's appropriation it was only found possible to include an amount of $500 for repairs and improvements at the schools on the Six Nations Reserve.

Due to scarcity of funds, the above mentioned amount cannot be exceeded.

You might let me know what repairs are urgently required, with an estimate of the cost, in the case of each school. In the event of material for any one school costing more than $50, you should forward a requisition so that purchase may be made through our Purchasing Branch.

We have received several vouchers from your office, in connection with school expenditure, without any authority being quoted. It would be appreciated if, in future, when forwarding vouchers, you would state the letter number and date of the authority. As you will realize, this information is necessary in order to permit us to control expenditure.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Major E. P. Randle,
Supt., Six Nations,
Brantford, Ont.

Sir:

In reply to your 32-1-5 of the 11th of July with reference to repairs and improvements to schools, the following recommendations are made:

(1) All the schools require minor repairs to doors, windows, fences, outhouses, etc., which with material and labour may cost approximately - $75.00

(2) 4 blinds 3' @ .80¢ 3.20
    18 blinds 3'6" @ 1.80 32.40 35.60

(3) Fencing No.3 School, labour and wire 65.00

(4) No.10 School, painting two coats,
    labour and paint 200.00
    No.5 School, painting two coats,
    labour and paint 100.00

(5) Eavestroughing No.9 School
    labour and material 35.00

(6) Clocks (four) @ 12.50 50.00

$560.60
As you know, we have about $75.00 worth of paint on hand, so the total amount will be less than that amount. If you approve, may an accountable cheque please be forwarded for $275.00 to cover payment of labour.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Major E. P. Randle,
Indian Superintendent.
Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of August 15 the Department approves the expenditures recommended therein. You should, however, send in requisitions for the material required for the No. 10 and No. 5 Schools as the expenditure in each case will be in excess of $50.00. As soon as these requisitions are received they will be turned over to the Purchasing Branch so that the material needed may be secured.

It is not necessary to state that this work should be completed before the opening of the schools.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Brantford, Ont.

Sir:

As you know, two of our day schools which entered
the School Improvement Competition last year did remarkably
well, both in the Provincial and the County competitions.

This year six of our Schools have entered, Nos.1,
3, 4, 6, 9 & 11, and though preferably I would rather have
seen less enter, now they have shown the keenness to enter I
feel that we should do all possible to encourage them.

As the programme laid out by the Competition officials
for each school is quite extensive, it was felt that the
Department could not be expected to do everything, so each
school collected salvage, or had some event whereby they man-
aged to obtain $15.00 to $20.00 each as funds towards providing
some of the things required.

Then at their last meeting the Council voted $75.00
to be divided up among the schools. This amount will go largely
in purchasing the various shrubs and plants required, for grass
seed, and for other ground improvements.

As far as the Department goes, I would like to have
authority to repair fences where necessary, mostly broken
posts, and some re-stretching. There will also be some stake
fencing to repair and general repairs to outbuildings, porches,
steps, mostly of a minor nature.

Then No.4 School should be painted on the outside,
as it has not been done during the time I have been in charge
of this Superintendency, and if possible on the inside. There
would also be some minor painting of fences and outbuildings.
where they are repaired, in the cases of schools entering
the competitions - in order they would conform to the re-
mainder of the woodwork adjoining.

There is, of course, a credit of $140.00 worth
of paint on hand, but a certain amount more would be re-
quired.

As these improvements etc. in order to gain points
for the schools, must be carried out before judging, I would
appreciate if you would see fit to let me know what sum is
available this year for improvements and labour, and then
allow me discretion in carrying them out as far as funds are
available, both to the schools in the competition and after-
wards the others. If you approve of this arrangement, may
an accountable cheque for $300.00 for labour be forwarded
immediately, please.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Major E. P. Randle,
Indian Superintendent.
Ottawa,

This was done last year, and it was found that the showing of the films to the school children aroused keen interest in ground improvements at our schools, and also at other Reserves where they were shown by Mr. Elliott Moses, apart from the general interest and pleasure the showing of the films gave to the general public of the Reserve when shown at public entertainments.

PERSONAL:

Mr. Philip Phelan, Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

This is just a personal note to see if you have any funds over, as in past years, to permit our buying paint etc. in advance for use on our schools next summer.

By painting two schools each year they are all kept in good shape, saving money in the long run, and it means every school gets attention about every six or seven years.

With kind regards,

Yours truly,

Lt.-Col. E.P. Randle,
Indian Superintendent.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

May this office please be advised of what funds are available for labour and purchase of materials for the repair and maintenance of Schools on the Six Nations and Mississauga Reserves.

There will be the usual minor repairs to all buildings and fences, some shingling, repairs to pumps and eavestroughing. It is not possible to estimate very closely on the cost of such work.

Some schools require several loads of stone screenings around their yards to do away with the muddy conditions during the Spring and Winter months. We can obtain such screenings for approximately 45¢ per ton laid down in the yards, and the total expenditure should not exceed $50.00.

Two schools require exterior painting, and we have the paint on hand, if the labour costs of around $150.00 could be provided by the Department.

Then the kitchen in the residence of No.11 schools requires plastering and papering, the total cost of which would be with labour, about $40.00.

Lt.-Col. E.P. Randle,

Indian Superintendent.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

With reference to repairs and maintenance to Indian Day Schools in this Superintendency, this office would recommend the following be done.

Nos. 1 and 7 require shingling throughout - which will take approximately 50 squares. The best No.1 Shingles 5X are quoted at $7.68 per square so the cost of shingles and nails would be about $385.00. Indian labour can be secured at $2.75 per square - costing $137.50, or a total approximate cost of $522.50.

No.7 School requires painting inside and out, and that at New Credit on the outside. As the paint is already on hand, there will be the labour costs, which will amount to approximately $250.00.

In addition there will be general repairs to fences, out-buildings, pumps etc., amounting to possibly $60.00 for material and $100.00 for labour.

Apart from the above repairs, this office would appreciate obtaining the following new equipment:- one new teacher's desk for the senior room at No.2 School, as the present one is very many years old and is completely beyond repair.

The No.4 and New Credit Schools require new clocks as the present ones are of most ancient vintage and no cleaning nor repair work puts them in running order. These can be secured as before locally at a price of $15.50 each, plus Government Tax of $3.88 each.

If the Department can authorize the above repairs, immediate advice would be appreciated, as workmen are all busy but must be secured at once in order repairs may be completed in time. May also the accountable cheque for $500.00 for wages please be forwarded with your approval.

-over
The shingles can be secured locally, and it is assumed need not be obtained through the Purchasing Agent as there would be sure to be delay.

Lt.-Col. E.P. Randle,

Indian Superintendent.

Re: School Repairs.

The following essential repairs and maintenance should be carried out during the holidays to keep the schools in proper condition.

Nos. 4 & 5 Schools.
These two schools require shingling, and the shingles are already on hand. They will require approximately 50 squares and the labour at $2.75 per square will amount to $137.50.

Nos. 4 & 11 Schools.
The three rooms of these two schools, hall-ways, etc. require inside painting, the paint being already on hand. The labour costs are estimated at $400.00.

Nos. 1 & 8 Schools.
The wire fencing around three sides of these schools is almost useless, and they should be rebuilt. It will take 70 rods of woven wire at .58¢ per rod, 70 posts at .40¢, 6 anchor posts and 6 braces at approximately $1.00 each, or including brace wire and staples, a total material cost of $85.00. In addition labour costs will be around $35.00.

In addition, there are general repairs such as broken posts, gates, pumps and outhouses, all requiring material and labour.

Some screenings will also be required to build up paths around buildings.

As labour is hard to get, this office would appreciate your immediate approval so we can make an early start; to make up for shortage of help. It is considered that labour costs will amount to $625.00.

Officers, and which I believe is officially known as Building No.49.

This office is in urgent need of a temporary school building, and it is considered that the above mentioned building is suitable in every way; and should it be possible to secure it we could arrange for its removal.

Ottawa, August 31, 1945.

Dear Sir:

This Department is anxious to secure, at the earliest possible date, a building that would be suitable for a school on the Six Nations Reserve, south of Brantford.

Our Superintendent, Lt.-Colonel E.P. Randle, Brantford, Ont., interviewed Squadron Leader Garland, Commanding Officer, 404 R.E.M.S., R.C.A.F., Jarvis, Ont.

There is a building at the Jarvis Station which would suit our purposes and could be easily moved to the reserve. It is the building that was formerly used as quarters of the W.D. Officers and I believe is officially known as Building No. 49.

Colonel Randle wrote to Squadron Leader Garland on August 17 with reference to this matter. I would appreciate an early reply, stating what further procedure we should follow in order to obtain this building.

Yours very truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

Re: Bldg. No.49 (W.D. Officers' Qtrs.)
No.494 R.E.M.S., Jarvis, Ontario

In reply to your letter dated August 31st, 1945, this Department has today declared as surplus Building No.49 (W.D. Officers' Quarters) to the Crown Assets Allocation Committee, with the comment that it be transferred to your Department for use as a school on the Six Nations Reserve.

Ottawa, October 13, 1945.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER,

Owing to increased attendance, an additional classroom is required at the Six Nations No. 1 Indian Day School. Lt.-Colonel E. P. Randle, Indian Superintendent, Brantford, Ont., ascertained that there was a building, surplus to requirements, at the Jarvis Air Station, which was recently closed. Colonel Randle states that this building could be easily moved to the reserve. It is the building that was formerly used as quarters of the W. D. officers and I understand is officially known as Building No. 49.

The Department of National Defence (Air) advise us that they have declared, as surplus, this building, to the Crown Assets Allocation Committee, with the comment that it be transferred to our Department for use as a school on the Six Nations Reserve.

I recommend that the Crown Assets Allocation Committee be requested to allot this building to us.

Director.

Ottawa, December 27, 1945.

Dear Colonel Randle:

Re: Building #49 - Officer's Quarters
Building #404 - R.E.M.S. Jarvis, Ont.

I had another enquiry today from the War Assets Corporation, requesting to be advised if we want the above building. I was under the impression that I had written to you in the matter, but I am unable to locate a copy of the letter. I am certain I phoned you because Inspector Arneil told me that when he was in your office two or three weeks ago you were endeavouring to obtain prices but up to that time had been unable to do so.

The terms on which we can secure the building are as follows:

1. The purpose of this letter is to ascertain whether or not your department is interested in purchase, our price being $500.00.

2. It should be clearly understood that this building will be sold on the following terms:

"Purchaser is required either to remove or demolish the building, removing all materials from the site, leaving it clean and tidy, levelling any excavations or mounds resulting from the original construction or demolition to the original contour of the ground, to the satisfaction of a duly authorized representative of War Assets Corporation."

The quotation which you will have to obtain is to carry out their requirement No. 2, keeping in mind
that it will also cost us the additional $500.00.

I wish you would give this matter your immediate attention and let me know, if possible, by Monday, next. I regret very much if this matter has been delayed due to any oversight of mine, but when I received the second letter from the War Assets this afternoon, I felt certain, as stated above, that I would find a copy of the letter to you on the file, but have not been able to do so.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

The undermentioned repairs to the various schools are recommended to be carried out during the holiday season:

N.S.

Painting - Nos. 1 & 6 Schools should be painted inside, while No. 9 School requires painting both inside and outside. Employing Indian painters it is estimated the labour costs will be approximately $355.00, while the paint is already on hand.

Shingling - No. 10 School requires complete shingling, and while we have the shingles on hand, the labour costs at $2.75 per square will be $60.00.

Fencing - No. 1 School requires a new fence which will take 50 rods of wire and approximately 60 posts, with of course, brace wire, staples, etc., at an estimated cost of $46.00. The labour for putting it up will be around $25.00.

General Repairs - There will be the usual general repairs, such as broken fences, doors, gates, outhouses and some eaves-troughing, and the labour costs will run up to about $125.00, with the material costs somewhat uncertain, but probably around $75.00.

If the Department will approve of these improvements and repairs, may an accountable cheque to cover labour costs be forwarded amounting to $565.00, while the material will be vouchered for in the usual way.

In addition there will be the two buildings we expect to acquire from the Military Training Camp to be used as temporary school rooms at Nos. 7 & 8 Schools.
The possibility of moving these and the cost has not yet been ascertained as the two firms contacted are busy moving other buildings elsewhere, but expect to be through shortly.

Also after removal there will be some costs fitting them up as school rooms, but that will be mostly labour costs - transferring desks, seats, cupboards and shelves.

Lt.-Col. E.P. Randle

Attention Mr. J. E. Morris:

Re: Hipples, Internment Camps

I have for acknowledgement your letter of November 13/46, regarding the freezing unit, electric motor, wire, pipe fitting, door, etc. and will be pleased to carry out your instruction regarding shipment of same to Indian Agent, MacKinnon, Sydney, Nova Scotia. In fact, I had a letter written to Mr. MacKinnon, asking him, if and when he could handle this unit, as I will be obliged to move it from its present storage at once.

I have on hand 8 camp or barrel stoves. These will each take a 4' stick of wood and are only suitable for camps or large buildings. I understood you were building a camp on the Restigouche reserve for lumbering, if so, probably you could use some of these stoves. They are not new, but are in fairly good condition. I have no use for them at the present time and feel that they would rust and spoil with age, if kept in storage.

We also have 3 large water tanks, and two jacket heaters (coal). These might be used to advantage, at some boarding school or other place, if not, we will move them to Kingsclear.

(Signed) Edward J. Whalen
Indian Agent
Ottawa, November 21, 1946.

Lt. Colonel E.P. Handle, Indian Superintendent,
Brantford, Ontario.

Stoves required for Indian Day Schools
Six Nations Reserve

The department has taken over part of an Internment Camp near Fredericton, New Brunswick. We are advised by Mr. Indian Agent Whalen that he has on hand four surplus camp or barrel stoves. These will each take a four foot stick of wood and should be suitable for heating your new schools, until a better type of stove can be purchased. They are not new but are in fairly good condition. Could we please be advised if you would care to have these stoves shipped to you.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training

The caretaker of the school lives nearby, but as her vision of the school is almost wholly screened by trees and bushes, she did not hear anything going on until almost the end, - when the breaking of glass drew her attention. Immediately proceeding to the school she did catch sight of one man, whom she thinks she can identify, disappearing across the fields. Eventually a passing car picked her up and drove her to the R.C.M.P. Police Barracks, and the police immediately proceeded there to investigate and obtain what evidence possible.

To date nothing of any definite nature has been established, as the man who the caretaker thinks she recognised has not yet been located.

This office is inclined to think that this damage may possibly have some connection with the animosity and bitterness of the Mohawk Workers against the Department and the Government. The whole school section is largely the residence of those who are such, and ever since the return of their delegation from Ottawa, feelings have been running high and many meetings have been held, and it is said they are quarreling over the way William Smith and Samuel Lickers presented their attitude to the Parliamentary Committee. There is also evidence of some Communist influence among them, which will be reported later. So, it is not improbable that some of these people, under the influence of drink, took this opportunity to display their ill-will in this manner.

Lt.-Col. E.F. Randle,
Indian Superintendent.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

This office regrets to advise you that some time on Saturday evening, No.1 School was broken into by apparently some intoxicated men, and a large amount of damage done, estimated at $250.00.

Every window in the school was broken including in most cases the sash; the teacher's desk and the clock were completely broken up, while the blackboards and school ladder were damaged, and books and papers were scattered all over the floor; one outhouse was demolished.

As the larger windows are eight feet in length, it may be some time before they can be replaced, as sash and glass are difficult to obtain.

In view of this the school will have to be closed for a few days, or maybe until September. If the sash and glass cannot be obtained immediately we shall have to board up all the windows, not only to prevent people getting in, but as this is the season of the year for heavy thunderstorms - to prevent heavy rains driving in and ruining the walls and floors, as the interior of this school was painted last year.

It would be appreciated if the Department would forward an accountable advance for $150.00 so we can pay the carpenters who will be employed repairing and cleaning up the mess.

May a teacher's desk also be ordered, as the one here is smashed beyond repair.

If the school remains closed, arrangements will be made to take care of the Entrance pupils elsewhere, and the other forms will have to be promoted on their year's work, as examinations have not yet been held.

The following essential repairs to the Day Schools should be carried out during the holiday season.

No.1 School
Painting on outside. Cost - paint, oil etc. $45.00, labour $100.00.
Woven wire fencing on three sides, and post and scantling fence at front. While it is not possible to estimate until the old fences are pulled down, exactly the number of posts and scantlings required, - the cost will be approximately material $65.00, and labour $35.00.

No.2 School
The flat tarred roof on this building is leaking in several places, and only expert roofers can repair this, but so far no firms engaged in this work have found time to come out and inspect it, - so the Department will perhaps leave this matter to my discretion.

No.6 School
This school, which includes a teacher's residence, must be painted inside and out. Cost of paint, oil, varnish etc., $80.00, - labour $180.00.
In addition, some of the panels of wall-board in the cloak rooms need replacing, as there are holes through them, and the steps and verandahs over the residence and boys' and girls' entrance require repairing, though the actual cost is difficult to estimate.

No.11 School
The stringers under the floor of the senior room have evidently given way through dry rot, and at least half the floor will have to be taken up and repaired as it has already dropped four inches. It is not possible to estimate either the time or material required for this until the floor is actually up, but
but it will not be under $100.00.

A new full double bed is required here for the residence - and we can obtain a suitable one for $17.95. Also the wood box stove in the senior room is beyond repair and must be replaced.

In addition to the major repairs outlined, there are considerable minor repairs to other schools, such as broken doors, steps, toilets, fences, sash. One chimney must be pulled down to the extent of five feet and rebuilt.

The old stake fences at No.7 and 8 schools, which had to be pulled down to admit the new school buildings, will have to be rebuilt and will then be repainted to conform to the rest of the schools.

Twenty blinds, 8' long, and six blinds 6' long are required, at approximately $4.00 and $1.50 each, are required as replacements.

Two wells require cleaning out at a cost of about $12.00 each.

Several schools require extra cupboard space for books and stationary, but as we cannot get suitable material we shall build them some shelves.

This office would request your approval to carry out these repairs, and would request an accountable advance of $600.00 be forwarded to cover labour costs.

In addition your attention is drawn to the fact that the new double-roomed school at No.8 and the manual training school at Ohsweken, have yet to be finished as regards painting and siding, apart from the contractor's work, which is about finished.

Lt.-Col.E.P.Randle, Indian Superintendent.

By your File 32-1-5 (Mt.1) of the 17th of July, you approved of various school repairs listed in our letter 2755/47 of the 14th of July and enclosed an accountable advance of $600.00.

However, as pointed out in our aforesaid letter, - apart from ordinary school repairs, there was considerable work to be done to finish the new double room at No.8 and the Manual Training School at Ohsweken.

The work that had to be done included labour siding the buildings with insul-brick, putting in shelves, cupboards, coat-hangers, eaves-troughing, moving and setting up toilets, also repairing and painting of fences taken down to admit buildings.

BRANTFORD, 25th Sept., 1947

B. F. Neary, Esq., Supt. Welfare and Training,
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

Re: Inspector's Report on Six Nations Schools.

This will acknowledge your letter of the 31st of July concerning recommendations made by the School Inspector, which we had not previously seen as Inspector Webster always sends his report direct to the Department.

With regard to the question of towels, this office is of the opinion that paper towels would be the most suitable in every way, as there would be great difficulty in getting the individual towels laundered and also to arrange suitable placement for them at the schools.

There might, of course, be some waste to paper towels, but that is a matter for the teacher to supervise and control. It is suggested that we issue them for a year and see as to the cost and the quantities used, and no doubt we could then tell as to whether unnecessary numbers are being used.

It would be best also to have the towel cabinets as advertised in the Geo.M.Hendry Company catalogue, under No.7-512, as they would probably help in economical use rather than the loose paper towels that many public places have.

The Water Container you refer to on Page 60 of the Hendry catalogue is suitable, and it would be satisfactory if we are supplied with them. Like the towels, the life of the containers would depend considerably on the supervision and discipline the teachers exercise over their class-rooms, as we have noticed in the use of water cups that some teachers have a much better system than others, and as a result much greater care is taken of them and their life is prolonged.

Indian Superintendent.

I, Ross Schurr, am prepared to transport the children of the Six Nations Indian Reserve to and from Hagersville High School also children from public schools to Manual Training Classes at Ohsweken and return to their local schools for 42 cents per mile as from the first of September 1st, 1949.

Signed. Ross Schurr
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

Re: School Bus Routes, Six Nations Superintendency, 1949-1950

As the present Academic Year is fast drawing to a close, it is probably wise to know the Departmental policy for the coming school year. Both the bus firms concerned who have been transporting the children to High School and the Manual Training Classes this year, are inquiring as to the possibilities of continuing next September. Mr. Schurr is prepared to continue transporting the children to Hagersville High School and to the Manual Training classes, but feels after his years experience that he should be paid at the rate of .42¢ per mile, rather than the .35¢ he now receives. A copy of his offer is attached.

Styres Bus Lines, Ohsweken, which is owned and operated by a member of the Six Nations, is prepared to continue carrying the children to Hagersville High School and also the Manual Training classes and is prepared to accept the same rate this year, .35¢ per mile. Styres Bus Lines are also in a position now, with two first-class Reo Busses, to take over all the School Bus Routes, if the Department consider the offer of Mr. Schurr too high.

Lt.-Col. E. P. Randle,
Indian Superintendent

With reference to your letter 466-5 (E.1) of 4th of May, we would appreciate receiving the accountable advance of $300.00 for labour, as we have completed siding the building and have no funds to pay labour costs.

WITNESSETH THAT in consideration of the mutual covenants, agreements and undertakings herein contained the Operator on behalf of himself, his heirs, executors, administrators and assigns, and the Party of the Second Part and their successors mutually covenant and agree as follows:

1. The Operator shall transport to and from the Six Nations and Mississaugas of the Credit Reservations the pupils as designated by the Party of the Second Part to the High Schools at Hagersville and Caledonia and those from the Day Schools receiving Manual and Home Economics Training at Ohsweken for the period covered by this contract. The estimated number being High School 57 pupils and Manual and Home Economics 160 Pupils.

2. The contract shall commence 6th September, 1949 and terminate 30th June, 1950.

3. The Operator shall use a motor vehicle properly licensed and insured as required by the Public Vehicle Act and the Regulations thereunder.

4. The Operator starting from the Village of Ohsweken shall follow the routes designated by the Indian Office, Brantford, and concurred in by the Operator.

5. The first pupil shall be picked up not later than 7:45 A.M. Roads and weather permitting, the vehicle shall arrive at the school at 8:20 A.M. It shall leave the school at 4:12 P.M. and shall follow the route in the opposite direction.

6. The cost of all insurance shall be paid by the Operator.

7. The Party of the Second Part shall pay to the Operator the sum of .35¢ per mile.

Enclosed please find return from four of my schools, the teachers asked me if they had not a report to make out the same as last year but I could not tell them as I had received no other forms than what I gave them.

I may say that I visited the schools and find what I consider to be poor attendance. The have very good school houses at Sagamore and Spanish schools. The teachers live in the schoolhouse and seem to be quite contented. To teach there attendance has not been very good owing to the Indians having been away working in the woods and having their families with them and as soon as they get back to the woods they have gone to Sugar Moccasin. The school at Cutler (Sagamore River Band) is I think doing pretty well at Mississauga they seem to get along fairly well.

At Sherraton they are not doing so very well as I would like there is a great many of the people opposed to the teachers and are continually making charges against him which when brought facts to hand they cannot make good. The teachers all complain that the parents are at fault as they will not compel their children to attend school and all wish something could be done to compel them to send their children to school regularly.
I think the teachers are all doing their duty as far as they can,
and I am in hopes we will get along better in the future.
When I visited Sagamook and Spanish
Schools I had a hard time of it. The
snow was deep and the weather very stormy.
I did not see many of the Indians.
I am his servant.

Samuel Haygar

Dear Mr. Hagan,

Referring to the Church of England Mission on the Spanish River. The first record we have of work done there by us was in the year two thousand eight hundred and seventy-five when four of the Indians were baptized by Rev. Portland Hill of Shingwauk. Visits were made to the Indians from time to time but no establishment was made on the way of building church or school.

I made my first visit in 1875, in the winter. I held Divine Service and...
contained my instructions. The following year I baptized an old man and his son. Then I visited the Indians at the Sugar Beach and baptized the family of Kauchibulgha who was formerly known as Big Indian John. There were five or six children—the eldest almost grown up. The following summer I baptized family of Wabaskishing and Ogahie connection. The mother's family were baptized—some of whom were very young. All these were heathen previously. Then Bishop Sullivan visited the village and arranged for funds to build a school house and place of worship. There were then from 25 to 30 persons members of the Church of England.

When the matter was proposed by Bishop Sullivan, his lordship emphasized the fact time to time that through Roman Catholic inhabitants there were Roman Catholics in effort had been made to establish a mission or a school. All the Indians agreed to support the school if it were built. The Indians worked building without any remuneration. The Bishop of the Department agreed supplying material. A teacher was found who wished to catechist under my direction. The Department sent the Church together supplying his salary. He left after several years work and the former stipend filled his place. Dear Sir,

About two months ago I saw at Wabigoon minister who lives on the shore of the Spanish River. He spoke to me of the so-called School of the Church of England that is on the other side of the river in the Indian reserve. That school, he said, has not been built by the Church of England, but by the Department with the money of the band; the majority of the Indians living there are members of the Catholic Church. Does it not seem that the school ought not to be a Church of England's school, but a public school, if not a Catholic separate school? Besides, he said, I see that the English minister holds his services in the school, whereas he likes, while the minister of the Catholic church, the priest cannot enjoy the same privilege, the key being refused to him.

Since then I notified the Priest in charge of those missions, Rev. Father Smith, and asked him to give the families and make an exact census of the population. Sadly, this Reverend Father wrote to me that there are on the River a total of 99 persons, 60 Catholics, 32 Protestants, 7 infidels. — Ten children about go to school, among whom only are Protestants, and beside them 2 sons of Bohemia are said to be now at the institution of Shingwak near Baie St. Marie.

May I ask you, dear sir, to look carefully into the case and to report to the Department. We ask that the school be no more a school of the Church of England, but a public school, and that as long as the majority of the children is Catholic and their teacher Protestant, no teaching of religion be given by that teacher; we ask besides that the priest as well as the minister may have the advantage to use this school building for religious service.
